elements.content: A new 3D fluorescent amide-functionalized Cd­(II)-based metal–organic framework (MOF) with molecular formula [Cd5Cl6(L)­(HL)2]·7H2O (1) was synthesized under solvothermal conditions using CdCl2·H2O and 4-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-N-[4-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)­phenyl]­benzamide (H2 L) in DMF/methanol in the presence of conc. HCl. Single-crystal X-diffraction analysis reveals that the 3D framework structure of 1 is constructed from octahedrally coordinated Cd2+ ions interconncted by chloride anions and ditopic tetrazolate-based ligand molecules. The phase-purity of the compound was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analysis, infrared spectroscopy, and elemental analysis. Thermogravimetric analysis suggests that 1 is thermally stable up to 300 °C. Steady-state fluorescence titration experiments reveal that activated 1′ can selectively detect 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) in the presence of other competing nitroaromatic compounds with a detection limit of 42.84 ppb. Recyclability experiments reveal that 1′ retains its initial fluorescence intensity even after several cycles, suggesting high photostability and reusability for long-term sensing applications. The extraordinarily selective fluorescence quenching is assigned to the presence of energy and electron transfer processes as well as the electrostatic interactions of the MOF with TNP. This new 3D amide-functionalized MOF is a potential candidate that can be developed into a highly selective and sensitive sensing device for the in-field detection of TNP.

This new 3D amide-functionalized MOF is a potential candidate that can be developed into a highly selective and sensitive sensing device for the in-field detection of TNP.

elements.content: Highly selective, sensitive, and prompt detection of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) by a new 3D fluorescent amide-functionalized tetrazolate-based Cd­(II) metal−organic framework material is presented. The selective detection of TNP in the presence of other nitroaromatic explosive compounds has been demonstrated. The mechanisms for the extraordinarily selective fluorescence quenching have been explored by employing a combined experimental and theoretical approach.
elements.clean_text: Highly selective, sensitive, and prompt detection of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) by a new 3D fluorescent amide-functionalized tetrazolate-based Cd(II) metal-organic framework material is presented. The selective detection of TNP in the presence of other nitroaromatic explosive compounds has been demonstrated. The mechanisms for the extraordinarily selective fluorescence quenching have been explored by employing a combined experimental and theoretical approach.

elements.content: The rapid and selective detection of nitro explosive compounds is very important for security screening, homeland security, environmental safety, and human health. The major industrial explosives include 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). 2,4,6-Trinitrophenol (TNP), which is a more powerful explosive than its well-known counterpart 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), has been extensively used in the manufacture of landmines, rocket fuels, fireworks, and matches. It is also frequently employed in leather, pharmaceutical, and dye industries. Owing to its widespread use, TNP has become a major environmental pollutant. Incontinent exposure of TNP to the environment from chemical industries severely affects the soil and aquatic system, causing various problems for wildlife and humans. Furthermore, mutagenic and/or carcinogenic activities of TNP can cause several health problems as well as fatal environmental pollution. Therefore, discriminative detection of TNP from other nitroexplosives with a very low detection limit is a crucial task to reduce its detrimental effects on the environment. The present in-field detection techniques for explosives employ sophisticated instruments, which suffer from low selectivity, limited portability, high cost, and enormous complexity. Owing to their high sensitivity, portability, simplicity, low cost, short response times, and dual compatibility in solid and solution media, fluorescence-based detection methods for nitro explosives have attracted growing attention in recent years. The fluorescent sensor materials, which have been used so far for the detection of nitro explosives, comprise conjugated polymers, nanoparticles, and metal–organic frameworks­(MOFs).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rapid and selective detection of nitro explosive compounds is very important for security screening, homeland security, environmental safety, and human health. The major industrial explosives include 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP). 2,4,6-Trinitrophenol (TNP), which is a more powerful explosive than its well-known counterpart 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), has been extensively used in the manufacture of landmines, rocket fuels, fireworks, and matches. It is also frequently employed in leather, pharmaceutical, and dye industries. Owing to its widespread use, TNP has become a major environmental pollutant. Incontinent exposure of TNP to the environment from chemical industries severely affects the soil and aquatic system, causing various problems for wildlife and humans. Furthermore, mutagenic and/or carcinogenic activities of TNP can cause several health problems as well as fatal environmental pollution. Therefore, discriminative detection of TNP from other nitroexplosives with a very low detection limit is a crucial task to reduce its detrimental effects on the environment. The present in-field detection techniques for explosives employ sophisticated instruments, which suffer from low selectivity, limited portability, high cost, and enormous complexity. Owing to their high sensitivity, portability, simplicity, low cost, short response times, and dual compatibility in solid and solution media, fluorescence-based detection methods for nitro explosives have attracted growing attention in recent years. The fluorescent sensor materials, which have been used so far for the detection of nitro explosives, comprise conjugated polymers, nanoparticles, and metal-organic frameworks(MOFs).

elements.content: MOFs, which are a comparatively new class of highly crystalline and extraordinarily porous materials, are built up of inorganic building units interconnected by rigid polytopic organic ligands. They have attracted tremendous research interest in the last two decades owing to their potential applications in a wide range of areas such as gas storage/separation, catalysis, sensing, polymerization, and drug delivery. In sharp contrast to conventional porous adsorbents (e.g., zeolites, mesoporous silicas, and activated carbons), the pore sizes and pore surface properties of MOFs can be modulated by changing the sizes of the ligands and by grafting different functional groups to the organic ligands, respectively. The porous crystalline structures of luminescent MOF materials provide advantages over other sensor materials. The ability to tune the sorption properties of MOFs provides a high degree of molecular specificity and selectivity for the detection of analytes. In addition to the size-selectivity, the large surface areas of MOFs along with confinement of the analytes within their pores can potentially result in high sensitivity detection of analytes. Moreover, the functional sites such as Lewis acidic or basic and open metal sites within porous MOFs can serve as specific recognition sites for the detection of different analytes. The selective accumulation of the targeted analyte within MOF cavities by these recognition sites can lead to increased detection performance. In addition, the incorporation of organic ligands in the rigid frameworks of MOFs results in stronger fluorescence emissions. Most of the luminescent MOF materials exhibit high stability to temperature and/or solvents, which is desirable for the practical application of a sensor material. Above all, the availability of a huge combination of metal ions and organic ligands allows fine-tuning of valence and/or conduction band (and hence optical band gap) of MOFs, which is very important for sensing applications. Inspired by the above-mentioned advantages, a broad variety of MOF materials have been synthesized and examined for the detection of a wide range of analytes including cations, anions, biomolecules, small molecules, volatile organic compounds, and nitro explosive materials.

elements.content: Although a large number of MOF-based fluorescent sensor materials have been investigated so far for the detection of nitro explosive compounds, only a few of them have exhibited prompt and selective sensing behavior toward TNP. In this report, we present a new fluorescent Cd­(II)-based MOF having molecular formula [Cd5Cl6(L)­(HL)2]·7H2O (1) and incorporating an amide-functionalized luminescent ditopic tetrazolate-based organic ligand. The activated form of the compound (denoted as 1′ hereafter) shows its potential for highly selective, sensitive, and rapid detection of TNP, even in the presence of other potentially interfering nitroaromatic explosive compounds. The combined experimental and theoretical approach described herein suggests that energy and electron transfer processes as well as electrostatic interactions of the MOF material with TNP play key roles in determining the unprecedented fluorescence quenching.
elements.clean_text: Although a large number of MOF-based fluorescent sensor materials have been investigated so far for the detection of nitro explosive compounds, only a few of them have exhibited prompt and selective sensing behavior toward TNP. In this report, we present a new fluorescent Cd(II)-based MOF having molecular formula [Cd5Cl6(L)(HL)2]⋅7H2O (1) and incorporating an amide-functionalized luminescent ditopic tetrazolate-based organic ligand. The activated form of the compound (denoted as 1' hereafter) shows its potential for highly selective, sensitive, and rapid detection of TNP, even in the presence of other potentially interfering nitroaromatic explosive compounds. The combined experimental and theoretical approach described herein suggests that energy and electron transfer processes as well as electrostatic interactions of the MOF material with TNP play key roles in determining the unprecedented fluorescence quenching.

elements.content: All the starting materials were of reagent grade and used as received from the commercial suppliers. The organic ligand H2 L was prepared by following a previously published procedure. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded in the region of 440–4000 cm–1 with a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two FT-IR spectrometer. The following indications are used to characterize absorption bands: very strong (vs), strong (s), medium (m), weak (w), shoulder (sh), and broad (br). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a SDT Q600 V20.9 Build 20 thermogravimetric analyzer in a temperature range of 25–900 °C under air atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1. Ambient temperature X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D2 Phaser X-ray diffractometer operated at 30 kV, 10 mA using Cu–Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation. Variable temperature XRPD patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance θ-2θ diffractometer in transmittance Bragg–Brentano geometry employing a Göbel mirror and Cu–Kα radiation. The patterns were recorded in an air atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–600 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C/min and 30 min isothermal steps required for collecting the diffraction data sets. The nitrogen sorption isotherms up to 1 bar were measured using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ-MP gas sorption analyzer at −196 °C. Prior to the sorption experiments, the compound was degassed at 120 °C for 12 h under dynamic vacuum. The UV–vis absorption spectra in solution were recorded with a PerkinElmer LAMBDA 750 UV–vis spectrophotometer. The solid-state UV–vis absorption spectra were collected on a JASCO V-650 UV–vis spectrophotometer by using a 150 mm integrating sphere. BaSO4 was used as an internal standard. Fluorescence emission studies were carried out with a HORIBA JOBIN YVON Fluoromax-4 spectrofluorometer. Fluorescence lifetimes were measured using time correlated single-photon counting (TCSPC) method on an Edinburgh Instrument Life-Spec II instrument. The samples were excited at 308 nm keeping the emission wavelength at 450 nm using a pulsed diode laser. The fluorescence decays were analyzed by reconvolution method using the FAST software provided by Edinburgh Instruments.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the starting materials were of reagent grade and used as received from the commercial suppliers. The organic ligand H2 L was prepared by following a previously published procedure. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded in the region of 440-4000 cm-1 with a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two FT-IR spectrometer. The following indications are used to characterize absorption bands: very strong (vs), strong (s), medium (m), weak (w), shoulder (sh), and broad (br). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a SDT Q600 V20.9 Build 20 thermogravimetric analyzer in a temperature range of 25-900 °C under air atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. Ambient temperature X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D2 Phaser X-ray diffractometer operated at 30 kV, 10 mA using Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation. Variable temperature XRPD patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance θ-2θ diffractometer in transmittance Bragg-Brentano geometry employing a Göbel mirror and Cu-Kα radiation. The patterns were recorded in an air atmosphere in the temperature range of 30-600 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C/min and 30 min isothermal steps required for collecting the diffraction data sets. The nitrogen sorption isotherms up to 1 bar were measured using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ-MP gas sorption analyzer at -196 °C. Prior to the sorption experiments, the compound was degassed at 120 °C for 12 h under dynamic vacuum. The UV-vis absorption spectra in solution were recorded with a PerkinElmer LAMBDA 750 UV-vis spectrophotometer. The solid-state UV-vis absorption spectra were collected on a JASCO V-650 UV-vis spectrophotometer by using a 150 mm integrating sphere. BaSO4 was used as an internal standard. Fluorescence emission studies were carried out with a HORIBA JOBIN YVON Fluoromax-4 spectrofluorometer. Fluorescence lifetimes were measured using time correlated single-photon counting (TCSPC) method on an Edinburgh Instrument Life-Spec II instrument. The samples were excited at 308 nm keeping the emission wavelength at 450 nm using a pulsed diode laser. The fluorescence decays were analyzed by reconvolution method using the FAST software provided by Edinburgh Instruments.

elements.content: Safety note! Metal azides, tetrazolate compounds, TNP and TNT are potentially explosive, and caution should be exercised when dealing with such materials. However, the small quantities used in this study were not found to present a hazard.

elements.content: CdCl2·H2O (24 mg, 0.12 mmol) and H2 L (20 mg, 0.06 mmol) ligand were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (1.5 mL) and MeOH (1.5 mL) by sonication for 15 min. After that, two drops of conc. HCl were added to the solution. The resulting solution was heated in a sealed glass tube at 80 °C for 2 days using a block heater. After spontaneous cooling to room temperature, colorless prism-shaped crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF (10 mL) and methanol (10 mL), and dried in air. The yield was 14 mg (0.007 mmol, 31%) based on the Cd salt. Anal. Calcd for C45H43N27O10Cd5Cl6 (1896.77): C, 28.83; H, 2.94; N, 19.76. Found: C, 28.50; H, 2.28; N, 19.93%. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3443 (br), 3350 (w), 3049–2776 (w), 1665 (vs), 1601 (m), 1544 (s), 1529 (sh), 1458 (s), 1417 (m), 1389 (w), 1327 (m), 1257 (w), 1157 (w), 1101 (w), 1009 (s), 900 (w), 861 (sh), 842 (m), 748 (m), 663 (w).

Synthesis

Synthesis of [Cd5Cl6(L)(HL)2]⋅7H2O (1)

CdCl2⋅H2O (24 mg, 0.12 mmol) and H2 L (20 mg, 0.06 mmol) ligand were dissolved in a mixture of DMF (1.5 mL) and MeOH (1.5 mL) by sonication for 15 min. After that, two drops of conc. HCl were added to the solution. The resulting solution was heated in a sealed glass tube at 80 °C for 2 days using a block heater. After spontaneous cooling to room temperature, colorless prism-shaped crystals were collected by filtration, washed with DMF (10 mL) and methanol (10 mL), and dried in air. The yield was 14 mg (0.007 mmol, 31%) based on the Cd salt. Anal. Calcd for C45H43N27O10Cd5Cl6 (1896.77): C, 28.83; H, 2.94; N, 19.76. Found: C, 28.50; H, 2.28; N, 19.93%. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3443 (br), 3350 (w), 3049-2776 (w), 1665 (vs), 1601 (m), 1544 (s), 1529 (sh), 1458 (s), 1417 (m), 1389 (w), 1327 (m), 1257 (w), 1157 (w), 1101 (w), 1009 (s), 900 (w), 861 (sh), 842 (m), 748 (m), 663 (w).

elements.content:
The as-synthesized form of 1 was heated at 120 °C under vacuum for 12 h in order to get the activated form of the compound (1′).

Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Structure of 1 was determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction intensities of 1 were recorded at 175 K on a Bruker D8 Quest diffractometer with a Photon 100 CMOS detector equipped with an Oxford Cryosystems 700 series cooler, a TRIUMPH monochromator, and a Mo Kα fine-focused sealed tube (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystals collected at lower temperatures appeared to crack in the cryostream. Initial structures were solved by XT and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques based on F2 using the SHELXTL package (version 6.14). Statistical information on the single-crystal data collection and refinement of 1 are summarized in Table S5, Supporting Information. The structure of 1 was found to be disordered at the six-membered ring and amide group. The entire ligand lies on a twofold rotation axis, which causes the disorder. Several attempts to split the disorder into separate parts were unsuccessful (atoms became nonpositive definite and refinement was unstable). In the end, the six-membered ring was refined using anisotropic parameters while a FRAG command was used to fix the coordinates of the amide. The amide itself was left isotropic, as all other attempts to split the amide or refine it anisotropically also proved unsuccessful. A disordered water molecule was found solvated within the structure. The oxygen atom of the water molecule lies on a threefold rotation axis and residual electron density surrounding the oxygen atom was refined as H atoms. Subsequent refinement placed both H atoms along the threefold symmetry causing deviated H–O–H bond angles and O–H distances, but further treatment using a combination of restraints gave poor results (again, atoms went nonpositive definite and refinement was unstable). The H atoms were left in the refinement for the purpose of proper formulation of the water molecule. It should be noted that a lower symmetry space group, P213, was attempted in order to remove the twofold rotation along the amide group; however, the amide was still clearly disordered. No indication of the presence of counterions was observed in the difference Fourier map or from the elemental analysis. The structural model having no counterions indicates that two-thirds of the tetrazole units of the ligands are protonated in order to maintain the electrostatic neutrality of the framework. Although protonation could not be observed in the difference Fourier map, it can be implied from elemental analysis and IR spectroscopy that protonation does occur. The bonding scheme as determined by the X-ray structure indicates that protonation occurs at N(2) atom. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the ligand resides in the HL –/L 2– deprotonation states. Similar deprotonation states have been formerly observed in two manganese MOFs incorporating ditopic tetrazolate-based ligands. CCDC-1420421 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: In order to make a stable suspension, 1.5 mg of 1′ was stirred in 3 mL of ethanol for 30 min and subsequently sonicated for 30 min. The resulting suspensions were allowed to stand undisturbed for 1 day before the fluorescence titration experiments. The fluorescence titration measurements were carried out by the gradual addition of 1 mM solution of various nitroaromatic explosives (up to 400 μL) to a 3 mL well-dispersed ethanol suspension of 1′. The solid-state fluorescence emission measurements were performed by exciting the compound at 356 nm. For all the fluorescence titration measurements, the excitation wavelength (λex) was 315 nm. The quenching efficiency was calculated by using (1 – I/I o) × 100%, where I o is the initial fluorescence intensity of 1′ dispersed in ethanol and I is the fluorescence intensity after addition of the analyte.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Quenching Titration

In order to make a stable suspension, 1.5 mg of 1' was stirred in 3 mL of ethanol for 30 min and subsequently sonicated for 30 min. The resulting suspensions were allowed to stand undisturbed for 1 day before the fluorescence titration experiments. The fluorescence titration measurements were carried out by the gradual addition of 1 mM solution of various nitroaromatic explosives (up to 400 μL) to a 3 mL well-dispersed ethanol suspension of 1'. The solid-state fluorescence emission measurements were performed by exciting the compound at 356 nm. For all the fluorescence titration measurements, the excitation wavelength (λex) was 315 nm. The quenching efficiency was calculated by using (1 - I/I o) × 100%, where I o is the initial fluorescence intensity of 1' dispersed in ethanol and I is the fluorescence intensity after addition of the analyte.

elements.content: In order to obtain the single crystals of 1, reactions were performed in various combinations of reactants at different temperatures. Two cadmium salts, namely, CdCl2·H2O and Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, were employed. The solvents used for these reactions included DMF, N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), ethanol, methanol, DMF/ethanol, DMF/methanol, DMA/ethanol, and DMA/methanol. The reaction temperatures ranged from 60 to 140 °C. Various metal salt/ligand molar ratios (1:1, 2:1, 3:1, and 4:1) were used. Very small crystals were obtained when a mixture of CdCl2·H2O and H2 L in a 2:1 molar ratio was heated at 80 °C in DMF/methanol (50:50, v/v) mixture. For increasing the size of the crystals, the same reaction was performed by adding various amounts (1–6 drops) of conc. HCl to the reaction mixture. Fortunately, the reaction mixture containing 2 drops of conc. HCl resulted in the formation of prism-shaped single-crystals, which were suitable for single-crystal XRD measurement. The addition of more than 2 drops of conc. HCl led to a decrease in the yield of the product. Good-quality single crystals having similar shapes were also achieved with Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O by applying the same procedure, except 3 drops of conc. HCl were added instead of 2 drops.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

In order to obtain the single crystals of 1, reactions were performed in various combinations of reactants at different temperatures. Two cadmium salts, namely, CdCl2⋅H2O and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, were employed. The solvents used for these reactions included DMF, N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), ethanol, methanol, DMF/ethanol, DMF/methanol, DMA/ethanol, and DMA/methanol. The reaction temperatures ranged from 60 to 140 °C. Various metal salt/ligand molar ratios (1:1, 2:1, 3:1, and 4:1) were used. Very small crystals were obtained when a mixture of CdCl2⋅H2O and H2 L in a 2:1 molar ratio was heated at 80 °C in DMF/methanol (50:50, v/v) mixture. For increasing the size of the crystals, the same reaction was performed by adding various amounts (1-6 drops) of conc. HCl to the reaction mixture. Fortunately, the reaction mixture containing 2 drops of conc. HCl resulted in the formation of prism-shaped single-crystals, which were suitable for single-crystal XRD measurement. The addition of more than 2 drops of conc. HCl led to a decrease in the yield of the product. Good-quality single crystals having similar shapes were also achieved with Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O by applying the same procedure, except 3 drops of conc. HCl were added instead of 2 drops.

elements.content: The as-synthesized crystals of 1 were thoroughly washed with DMF after filtration for the removal of the physisorbed DMF molecules from the external surface. After that, the compound was heated at 120 °C under vacuum in order to remove the occluded water molecules from the pores. In this way, the activated form of the compound (1′) was obtained.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in a cubic crystal system within space group P4132 and exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) framework structure (d). The asymmetric unit of compound 1 (Figure S1, Supporting Information) consists of two crystallographically independent Cd2+ ions (Cd(1) lies on a twofold rotation axis with occupancy of 1/2 whereas Cd(2) lies on a threefold rotation axis with occupancy of 1/3), half of the H2 L ligand molecule (a) and one μ2-Cl atom. Each Cd2+ ion resides in a distorted octahedral environment. The two types of Cd2+ ions are arranged in an alternative fashion having two different types of coordination environments (b). In the first type of coordination environment, which contains a CdCl2N4 unit, each Cd(1) atom is coordinated with two μ2-Cl atoms and four N atoms from four different H2 L ligand molecules. On the other hand, the second type of coordination environment consists of a CdCl3N3 unit. In this case, every Cd(2) atom is connected with three μ2-Cl atoms and three N atoms from three different H2 L ligand molecules. Each ditopic tetrazolate-based ligand molecule is bound with six Cd2+ ions through three N atoms of each tetrazolate ring. Thus, each H2 L ligand molecule shows η3:μ6 coordinating motif. As shown in , only one type of binding mode (Mode VIII) is present in the structure of compound 1 among all possible binding modes of tetrazole ring. Such binding mode of the tetrazole moiety has been reported in the literature for only a few metal-tetrazolate coordination polymers. The adjacent Cd2+ ions are interconnected by the bridging Cl atoms and ligand molecules, leading to a 3D, noninterpenetrated network structure (c). If the bridging ligand molecules are omitted, the resulting framework structure (d) can be imagined to possess larger oval- and smaller square-shaped pores. The selected bond distances and angles are shown in Table S1, Supporting Information. The Cd–N bond distances vary from 2.343(7) to 2.489(8) Å, whereas the two kinds of Cd–Cl bond distances are 2.601(2) and 2.596(2) Å. The Cd–N bond distances observed in the present compound are in agreement with those of the formerly reported Cd-tetrazolate MOFs. According to the program PLATON, the total potentially accessible void volume is 3521.7 Å3, which is 39% of the unit cell volume (9040.5 Å3). Under ambient conditions, these void regions of the network are occupied by seven water molecules per formula unit, which is in agreement with the thermogravimetric (TG) and elemental analysis. Despite having considerable pore volume, the N2 sorption analysis (Figure S2, Supporting Information) indicated that compound 1 is nonporous toward N2 (specific BET surface area: 4 m2 g–1). This fact can be related to the very small pore apertures, which restricts the passage of relatively larger N2 molecules into the framework of compound 1.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in a cubic crystal system within space group P4132 and exhibits a three-dimensional (3D) framework structure (d). The asymmetric unit of compound 1 (Figure S1, Supporting Information) consists of two crystallographically independent Cd2+ ions (Cd(1) lies on a twofold rotation axis with occupancy of 1/2 whereas Cd(2) lies on a threefold rotation axis with occupancy of 1/3), half of the H2 L ligand molecule (a) and one μ2-Cl atom. Each Cd2+ ion resides in a distorted octahedral environment. The two types of Cd2+ ions are arranged in an alternative fashion having two different types of coordination environments (b). In the first type of coordination environment, which contains a CdCl2N4 unit, each Cd(1) atom is coordinated with two μ2-Cl atoms and four N atoms from four different H2 L ligand molecules. On the other hand, the second type of coordination environment consists of a CdCl3N3 unit. In this case, every Cd(2) atom is connected with three μ2-Cl atoms and three N atoms from three different H2 L ligand molecules. Each ditopic tetrazolate-based ligand molecule is bound with six Cd2+ ions through three N atoms of each tetrazolate ring. Thus, each H2 L ligand molecule shows η3:μ6 coordinating motif. As shown in , only one type of binding mode (Mode VIII) is present in the structure of compound 1 among all possible binding modes of tetrazole ring. Such binding mode of the tetrazole moiety has been reported in the literature for only a few metal-tetrazolate coordination polymers. The adjacent Cd2+ ions are interconnected by the bridging Cl atoms and ligand molecules, leading to a 3D, noninterpenetrated network structure (c). If the bridging ligand molecules are omitted, the resulting framework structure (d) can be imagined to possess larger oval- and smaller square-shaped pores. The selected bond distances and angles are shown in Table S1, Supporting Information. The Cd-N bond distances vary from 2.343(7) to 2.489(8) Å, whereas the two kinds of Cd-Cl bond distances are 2.601(2) and 2.596(2) Å. The Cd-N bond distances observed in the present compound are in agreement with those of the formerly reported Cd-tetrazolate MOFs. According to the program PLATON, the total potentially accessible void volume is 3521.7 Å3, which is 39% of the unit cell volume (9040.5 Å3). Under ambient conditions, these void regions of the network are occupied by seven water molecules per formula unit, which is in agreement with the thermogravimetric (TG) and elemental analysis. Despite having considerable pore volume, the N2 sorption analysis (Figure S2, Supporting Information) indicated that compound 1 is nonporous toward N2 (specific BET surface area: 4 m2 g-1). This fact can be related to the very small pore apertures, which restricts the passage of relatively larger N2 molecules into the framework of compound 1.

X-ray Powder Diffraction and FT-IR Analysis

The phase purity of 1 was verified by using XRPD patterns recorded from as-synthesized 1 at ambient conditions. The experimental XRPD pattern (Figure S3, Supporting Information) of as-synthesized 1 matches closely with the simulated XRPD pattern obtained from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. The thermally activated 1' retains its crystallinity, as confirmed from the XRPD patterns (Figure S3, Supporting Information) of the corresponding sample.

elements.content: In the FT-IR spectrum (Figure S4, Supporting Information) of 1, the strong absorption band at 1665 cm–1 can be assigned to the CO stretching vibration of the amide group of the ligand molecules. The absorption bands owing to the N–H stretching and bending vibrations of the amide group of the ligand molecules are located at 3350 and 1544 cm–1, respectively.

elements.content: In order to investigate the thermal stability of 1, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in the temperature range of 25–900 °C in an air atmosphere. According to the TG analysis, 1 is stable up to 300 °C. In the TG curve of 1 (Figure S5, Supporting Information), the first weight loss step of 6.1 wt % in the temperature range of 25–80 °C can be attributed to the removal of seven guest water molecules per formula unit (calcd.: 6.6 wt %). No further weight loss step is observed below the decomposition temperature (300 °C) of 1. Above 300 °C, the compound starts to decompose due to the loss of the organic linker molecules from the framework. In the TG trace of 1′, the one weight loss step below the decomposition temperature can be attributed to the removal of absorbed water molecules. The exposure of 1′ to air after thermal activation presumably led to hydration of the compound.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

In order to investigate the thermal stability of 1, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in the temperature range of 25-900 °C in an air atmosphere. According to the TG analysis, 1 is stable up to 300 °C. In the TG curve of 1 (Figure S5, Supporting Information), the first weight loss step of 6.1 wt % in the temperature range of 25-80 °C can be attributed to the removal of seven guest water molecules per formula unit (calcd.: 6.6 wt %). No further weight loss step is observed below the decomposition temperature (300 °C) of 1. Above 300 °C, the compound starts to decompose due to the loss of the organic linker molecules from the framework. In the TG trace of 1', the one weight loss step below the decomposition temperature can be attributed to the removal of absorbed water molecules. The exposure of 1' to air after thermal activation presumably led to hydration of the compound.

elements.content: The high thermal stability of 1′ was also verified by variable temperature XRPD experiments (Figure S6, Supporting Information), which disclosed that the compound is stable up to 300 °C. This result is in agreement with that obtained from the thermogravimetric analyses.

elements.content: MOFs based on d10 metal ions with π-conjugated aromatic ligands are well-known for their excellent luminescence behavior and thus considered as potential candidates for applications as sensors. Since 1′ is constructed from d10 (Cd2+) metal ions and π-electron-rich conjugated organic ligand, it was hypothesized to be a potential fluorophore with tremendous photoluminescence (PL) properties. The solid-state fluorescence emission spectrum of the H2 L ligand () shows an emission maximum at 456 nm upon excitation at 344 nm, which can be assigned to the intraligand π–π* transition of the aromatic rings. On the other hand, 1′ () displays an emission maximum at 470 nm in the solid state upon excitation at 356 nm. The similarity between the emission bands of H2 L ligand and 1′ indicates that the photoluminescence behavior of 1′ is mainly due to ligand-centered electronic excitation. However, a red shift (14 nm) of the emission band of the compound compared to the parent ligand is observed, which can be attributed to the perturbation caused by the complexation of the ligand with Cd2+ ions.

Photoluminescence Properties

MOFs based on d10 metal ions with π-conjugated aromatic ligands are well-known for their excellent luminescence behavior and thus considered as potential candidates for applications as sensors. Since 1' is constructed from d10 (Cd2+) metal ions and π-electron-rich conjugated organic ligand, it was hypothesized to be a potential fluorophore with tremendous photoluminescence (PL) properties. The solid-state fluorescence emission spectrum of the H2 L ligand () shows an emission maximum at 456 nm upon excitation at 344 nm, which can be assigned to the intraligand π-π* transition of the aromatic rings. On the other hand, 1' () displays an emission maximum at 470 nm in the solid state upon excitation at 356 nm. The similarity between the emission bands of H2 L ligand and 1' indicates that the photoluminescence behavior of 1' is mainly due to ligand-centered electronic excitation. However, a red shift (14 nm) of the emission band of the compound compared to the parent ligand is observed, which can be attributed to the perturbation caused by the complexation of the ligand with Cd2+ ions.

elements.content: The photoluminescence behavior of 1′ (Figure S7, Supporting Information) in common organic solvents (tetrahydrofuran, benzene, dichloromethane, DMF, ethanol, chloroform, methanol, acetonitrile, 2-propanol, toluene, acetone, and nitrobenzene) was also investigated. All the fluorescence emission experiments were performed with a stable suspension of 1′ (1.5 mg) in different organic solvents (3 mL). An ethanol suspension of 1′ showed the strongest emission band at 450 nm upon excitation at 315 nm at room temperature. Hence, all the fluorescent experiments were performed in ethanol. Due to the instability of 1′ in water (as revealed from the XRPD analysis), the luminescence behavior of the compound in water was not investigated.

elements.content: The highly fluorescent nature of 1′ in both solution and solid state inspired us to explore its potential applications as a sensor for the detection of nitroaromatic explosives (NAEs). The NAEs, which were used for this work, included 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP; commonly known as picric acid), 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP), p-nitrophenol (PNP), 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), and nitrobenzene (NB). In order to investigate the applicability of electron-rich compound 1′ as a promising detecting device for electron-deficient NAEs, the fluorescence behavior of 1′ in the presence of the NAEs was examined. For this purpose, fluorescent titration measurements were performed by the gradual addition of 1 mM ethanol solution of the NAEs to the well-dispersed suspensions of 1′ in ethanol. A successive quenching of the fluorescence intensity of 1′ was observed upon incremental addition of the analytes (Figures S8–S15, Supporting Information). It is remarkable that the visible light blue emission of 1′ under UV light disappeared after addition of 400 μL of 1 mM TNP solution, which resulted in nearly 92% quenching of the initial fluorescence intensity (). A small red shift (10 nm) of the emission band upon increasing addition of TNP solution could be a consequence of an energy transfer mechanism occurring between the analyte and the compound. The detection performance of 1′ for other nitroaromatic explosives () was very low and the lowest quenching efficiency was observed for NB. The quenching efficiencies for the selected analytes decreased in the sequence: TNP > PNP > DNP > TNT > 4-NT > 2,4-DNT > 2,6-DNT > 1,3-DNB > NB. This sequence is not completely in agreement with the trend of electron-deficient nitro groups present in the analytes.

The highly fluorescent nature of 1' in both solution and solid state inspired us to explore its potential applications as a sensor for the detection of nitroaromatic explosives (NAEs). The NAEs, which were used for this work, included 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP; commonly known as picric acid), 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP), p-nitrophenol (PNP), 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,6-dinitrotoluene (2,6-DNT), 4-nitrotoluene (4-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), and nitrobenzene (NB). In order to investigate the applicability of electron-rich compound 1' as a promising detecting device for electron-deficient NAEs, the fluorescence behavior of 1' in the presence of the NAEs was examined. For this purpose, fluorescent titration measurements were performed by the gradual addition of 1 mM ethanol solution of the NAEs to the well-dispersed suspensions of 1' in ethanol. A small red shift (10 nm) of the emission band upon increasing addition of TNP solution could be a consequence of an energy transfer mechanism occurring between the analyte and the compound. The detection performance of 1' for other nitroaromatic explosives () was very low and the lowest quenching efficiency was observed for NB. The quenching efficiencies for the selected analytes decreased in the sequence: TNP > PNP > DNP > TNT > 4-NT > 2,4-DNT > 2,6-DNT > 1,3-DNB > NB. elements.content: In order to study the quenching efficiency of TNP in the presence of other NAEs, fluorescence titration experiments were carried out by the gradual addition of 1.43 × 10–4 M TNP solution to the suspension of 1′ containing 1.43 × 10–4 M solution of other NAEs (Figures S16–S23, Supporting Information). As shown in , the quenching efficiency of TNP remains almost the same in the presence of other NAEs, except for NB where quenching efficiency decreases by nearly 20%. These results clearly show the high selectivity of 1′ for TNP, even in the presence of a higher concentration of other NAEs.

elements.content: In order to investigate the recyclability of 1′, the material was recovered after every fluorescence titration experiment (with 1 mM TNP solution) by centrifugation, followed by washing with ethanol several times. Remarkably, the compound almost regains its initial fluorescence intensity and quenching efficiency over 5 cycles of repetition (). As confirmed by the XRPD measurements (Figure S24, Supporting Information), 1′ maintained its crystallinity (and hence structural integrity) after 5 repeated cycles of fluorescence titration experiments with 1 mM TNP solution. These results imply high photostability and reusability of the material, making it potentially applicable for long-term in-field detection of explosive compounds.

elements.content: Quenching of fluorescence intensity can occur by two quenching processes: collision or dynamic quenching and complex formation or static quenching. Dynamic quenching takes place when the excited fluorophore comes in contact with the quencher molecule, which facilitates nonradiative transition to the ground state. This process leads to quenching of the fluorescence intensity. On the other hand, the static quenching involves formation of a nonfluorescent stable complex (dark complex) between the fluorophore and the quencher molecule. If only one type of quenching process is taking place, the quenching can be expressed by the Stern–Volmer equation, (I 0/I) = K sv [A] + 1, where I 0 is the initial fluorescence intensity before addition of analyte, I is the fluorescence intensity after addition of analyte, [A] is the molar concentration of analyte, and K sv is the quenching constant (in M–1). In order to determine the Stern–Volmer binding constant (K sv), a steady-state fluorescence measurement was performed. The S–V plot for TNP at low concentrations () showed a linear curve, indicating that either dynamic or static quenching is taking place, but the deviation of the S–V plot from linearity at higher concentrations (inset of ) suggests the presence of both dynamic and static quenching processes. The K sv value from the linear portion of the S–V plot for TNP toward luminescent 1′ was estimated to be 4.05 × 104 M–1. This is among the highest values reported (Table S2, Supporting Information) so far for MOF-based sensor materials. The distinction between the two quenching mechanisms can be predicted by performing time-resolved fluorescence measurements of photoluminescence decay of the fluorophore at different concentrations of the quencher. If the fluorescence lifetime of the sensor material is reduced, the quenching process is regarded as dynamic because additional relaxation of the excited-state lifetime in this process results from the collision with the quencher. However, if the fluorescence lifetime of the sensor material remains unaltered after incremental addition of the quencher, it is considered a static quenching process. The time-resolved fluorescence experiments () revealed that the average excited-state lifetimes (⟨τ⟩) of 1′ are 1.12 and 1.09 ns (Table S3, Supporting Information) before and after addition of 400 μL TNP, respectively. These average lifetime values suggest that the quenching process is predominantly static in nature.

elements.content: In order to determine the response time for the sensing of TNP by 1′, time-dependent fluorescence investigations were carried out at four different concentrations of TNP (100, 200, 300, and 400 μL of 1 mM TNP solutions added to a 3 mL suspension of 1′ in ethanol). At a particular concentration of TNP, the fluorescence intensity of 1′ was monitored at regular time intervals up to 320 s of exposure time. The plots of quenching efficiencies versus exposure times () reveal that the addition of 400 μL of TNP to the ethanol suspension of 1′ results in very fast detection of the former. At this concentration of TNP, it takes only a few seconds (<25 s) to achieve almost complete quenching (92%) of the initial fluorescence intensity of 1′.

Response Time of 1' toward Detection of TNP

In order to determine the response time for the sensing of TNP by 1', time-dependent fluorescence investigations were carried out at four different concentrations of TNP (100, 200, 300, and 400 μL of 1 mM TNP solutions added to a 3 mL suspension of 1' in ethanol). At a particular concentration of TNP, the fluorescence intensity of 1' was monitored at regular time intervals up to 320 s of exposure time. The plots of quenching efficiencies versus exposure times () reveal that the addition of 400 μL of TNP to the ethanol suspension of 1' results in very fast detection of the former. elements.content: In order to obtain the limit of detection for TNP toward 1′, a very low concentration of TNP (μM) solution was added incrementally to 1′ dispersed in ethanol and the fluorescence quenching was monitored. The plot of change in fluorescence intensity versus concentration of TNP revealed a linear curve () with a slope (K) of 2 × 1010 and correlation coefficient (R 2) of 0.9965. The limit of detection (LOD) was calculated by using the equation: LOD = 3σ/K, where σ is the standard deviation of initial intensity of 1′ without analyte and K denotes the slope of the above-mentioned linear curve. The detection limit of 1′ for sensing of TNP was found to be 1.87 × 10–7 M (42.84 ppb), which is comparable with other reported (Table S2, Supporting Information) MOF-based sensor materials.

elements.content: The sensing mechanism was investigated in order to realize the high selectivity of 1′ for TNP. For all the NAEs, only surface adsorption is expected to occur due to the smaller pore apertures of the framework structure of 1′. A photoinduced electron transfer mechanism can be hypothesized for the highly selective sensing of NAEs by 1′. In spite of their extended network structures, MOFs often possess definite band gap energies due to the highly localized electronic structures (especially for MOFs with d10 metal ions). Usually, the lowest unoccupied MOs (LUMOs) of the electron-deficient NAEs reside between the valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) of the luminescent MOFs. Efficient transfer of electrons can occur from the CB of 1′ to the LUMO of NAEs, thus quenching the fluorescence intensity upon excitation. The HOMO and LUMO orbital energies (Table S4, Supporting Information) for the H2 L ligand and the selected analytes are depicted in . They were determined by the density functional theory (DFT) at B3LYP/6-31G* accuracy level using the Gaussian 09 package of programs. As shown in , the photoluminescence behavior of 1′ is ligand-centered. The LUMO energy of the electron-rich H2 L ligand was calculated to be −1.8757 eV, which is higher than those of the tested NAEs (−2.2213 to −3.898 eV). These LUMO energy values suggest that the excited state electron transfer from 1′ to the NAEs can take place effectively. The estimated LUMO energy values of the analytes increase in the order: TNP < TNT < DNB < 2,4-DNT < 2,6-DNT < DNP < NB < 4-NT < PNP. The ease of electron transfer to the electron-deficient analytes should follow the reverse trend. Thus, the lowest LUMO energy value of TNP is in good agreement with the maximum quenching observed for this analyte. However, the sequence of experimental quenching efficiencies (i.e., TNP > PNP > DNP > TNT > 4-NT > 2,4-DNT > 2,6-DNT > 1,3-DNB > NB) is not completely in agreement with the LUMO energies of other NAEs. Therefore, photoinduced electron transfer is not the only mechanism for the observed quenching. Long-range energy transfer might also be operative in the quenching process.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanisms for the Detection of Nitroaromatic Explosives

The sensing mechanism was investigated in order to realize the high selectivity of 1' for TNP. For all the NAEs, only surface adsorption is expected to occur due to the smaller pore apertures of the framework structure of 1'. A photoinduced electron transfer mechanism can be hypothesized for the highly selective sensing of NAEs by 1'. In spite of their extended network structures, MOFs often possess definite band gap energies due to the highly localized electronic structures (especially for MOFs with d10 metal ions). Usually, the lowest unoccupied MOs (LUMOs) of the electron-deficient NAEs reside between the valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) of the luminescent MOFs. Efficient transfer of electrons can occur from the CB of 1' to the LUMO of NAEs, thus quenching the fluorescence intensity upon excitation. The HOMO and LUMO orbital energies (Table S4, Supporting Information) for the H2 L ligand and the selected analytes are depicted in . They were determined by the density functional theory (DFT) at B3LYP/6-31G* accuracy level using the Gaussian 09 package of programs. As shown in , the photoluminescence behavior of 1' is ligand-centered. The LUMO energy of the electron-rich H2 L ligand was calculated to be -1.8757 eV, which is higher than those of the tested NAEs (-2.2213 to -3.898 eV). These LUMO energy values suggest that the excited state electron transfer from 1' to the NAEs can take place effectively. The estimated LUMO energy values of the analytes increase in the order: TNP < TNT < DNB < 2,4-DNT < 2,6-DNT < DNP < NB < 4-NT < PNP. The ease of electron transfer to the electron-deficient analytes should follow the reverse trend. Thus, the lowest LUMO energy value of TNP is in good agreement with the maximum quenching observed for this analyte. However, the sequence of experimental quenching efficiencies (i.e., TNP > PNP > DNP > TNT > 4-NT > 2,4-DNT > 2,6-DNT > 1,3-DNB > NB) is not completely in agreement with the LUMO energies of other NAEs. Therefore, photoinduced electron transfer is not the only mechanism for the observed quenching. Long-range energy transfer might also be operative in the quenching process.

elements.content: Resonance energy transfer from the fluorophore of the organic ligand to nonemissive analytes can occur if the absorption bands of the analytes have an effective overlap with the emission band of the fluorophore. The effective energy transfer enhances the fluorescence quenching efficiency of the analyte. It is observed from that the absorption band of TNP has a large overlap with the emission band (450 nm) of 1′, whereas other analytes have less or almost no overlap. The maximum overlap between the absorption band of TNP and the emission band of 1′ (as compared to other analytes) is in agreement with the highest quenching efficiency of TNP. The spectral overlap suggests that the fluorescence quenching by TNP occurs by an energy transfer mechanism. This mechanism can be also evidenced by the red shift of the fluorescent intensity () observed during incremental addition of TNP solution to a suspension of 1′. Evidence in favor of energy transfer mechanism can also be obtained from the nonlinearity of the S–V plots (inset of ) at higher concentrations.

elements.content: The highest quenching efficiency of TNP may also be related to the strong electrostatic interactions between the Lewis basic amide group of H2 L ligand and the highly acidic hydroxyl group of TNP. The presence of an amide group in the H2 L ligand increases the surface area of interaction of 1′ with the acidic hydroxyl groups of TNP via hydrogen bonding and ionic interactions. This increase in surface interaction between the host and the analyte leads to a turn-off fluorescence response for TNP. Other analytes (except DNP and PNP) do not possess any acidic hydroxyl group in order to interact with the free basic amide sites of the ligand. Thus, the above-mentioned electrostatic interactions are absent in the other analytes, leading to significantly lower quenching performance. Overall, the combined effects of energy and electron transfer mechanisms as well as electrostatic interactions may be attributed to the high selectivity of 1′ for the detection of TNP.

elements.content: A strongly fluorescent 3D Cd­(II)-based MOF (1) incorporating a highly π-conjugated amide-functionalized ditopic tetrazolate-based organic ligand has been successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions. The activated compound (1′) can selectively detect TNP with a very high rate of response, as confirmed by the steady-state fluorescence titration experiments. The selective detection of TNP in the presence of other potentially interfering nitroaromatic explosives has also been demonstrated. The detection limit of 1′ for the sensing of TNP was estimated to be 1.87 × 10–7 M (42.84 ppb), which is comparable with other MOF-based fluorescence sensors reported up to the present date. The recyclability experiments imply high photostability and reusability of 1′ for long-term in-field detection of nitroaromatic explosive materials. The combination of experimental and theoretical results provides indications in favor of both energy and electron transfer mechanisms for the highest quenching efficiency of TNP. Moreover, the enhanced selectivity of 1′ for sensing of TNP can be intuitively attributed to the existence of electrostatic interactions between the N–H moiety of the ligand and the hydroxyl group of TNP. The outstanding sensing performance renders the material as a promising sensing device for the practical detection of TNP.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A strongly fluorescent 3D Cd(II)-based MOF (1) incorporating a highly π-conjugated amide-functionalized ditopic tetrazolate-based organic ligand has been successfully synthesized under solvothermal conditions. The activated compound (1') can selectively detect TNP with a very high rate of response, as confirmed by the steady-state fluorescence titration experiments. The selective detection of TNP in the presence of other potentially interfering nitroaromatic explosives has also been demonstrated. The detection limit of 1' for the sensing of TNP was estimated to be 1.87 × 10-7 M (42.84 ppb), which is comparable with other MOF-based fluorescence sensors reported up to the present date. The recyclability experiments imply high photostability and reusability of 1' for long-term in-field detection of nitroaromatic explosive materials. The combination of experimental and theoretical results provides indications in favor of both energy and electron transfer mechanisms for the highest quenching efficiency of TNP. Moreover, the enhanced selectivity of 1' for sensing of TNP can be intuitively attributed to the existence of electrostatic interactions between the N-H moiety of the ligand and the hydroxyl group of TNP. The outstanding sensing performance renders the material as a promising sensing device for the practical detection of TNP.

cln_elements.content:
A new 3D fluorescent amide-functionalized Cd­(II)-based metal–organic framework (MOF) with molecular formula [Cd5Cl6(L)­(HL)2]·7H2O (1) was synthesized under solvothermal conditions using CdCl2·H2O and 4-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-N-[4-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)­phenyl]­benzamide (H2 L) in DMF/methanol in the presence of conc. HCl. Single-crystal X-diffraction analysis reveals that the 3D framework structure of 1 is constructed from octahedrally coordinated Cd2+ ions interconncted by chloride anions and ditopic tetrazolate-based ligand molecules. The phase-purity of the compound was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) analysis, infrared spectroscopy, and elemental analysis. Thermogravimetric analysis suggests that 1 is thermally stable up to 300 °C. Steady-state fluorescence titration experiments reveal that activated 1′ can selectively detect 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) in the presence of other competing nitroaromatic compounds with a detection limit of 42.84 ppb. Recyclability experiments reveal that 1′ retains its initial fluorescence intensity even after several cycles, suggesting high photostability and reusability for long-term sensing applications. The extraordinarily selective fluorescence quenching is assigned to the presence of energy and electron transfer processes as well as the electrostatic interactions of the MOF with TNP. This new 3D amide-functionalized MOF is a potential candidate that can be developed into a highly selective and sensitive sensing device for the in-field detection of TNP.

Thermal Stability

In order to investigate the thermal stability of 1, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in the temperature range of 25–900 °C in an air atmosphere. According to the TG analysis, 1 is stable up to 300 °C. In the TG curve of 1 (Figure S5, Supporting Information), the first weight loss step of 6.1 wt % in the temperature range of 25–80 °C can be attributed to the removal of seven guest water molecules per formula unit (calcd.: 6.6 wt %). No further weight loss step is observed below the decomposition temperature (300 °C) of 1. Above 300 °C, the compound starts to decompose due to the loss of the organic linker molecules from the framework. In the TG trace of 1′, the one weight loss step below the decomposition temperature can be attributed to the removal of absorbed water molecules. The exposure of 1′ to air after thermal activation presumably led to hydration of the compound.

Photoluminescence Properties

MOFs based on d10 metal ions with π-conjugated aromatic ligands are well-known for their excellent luminescence behavior and thus considered as potential candidates for applications as sensors. Since 1′ is constructed from d10 (Cd2+) metal ions and π-electron-rich conjugated organic ligand, it was hypothesized to be a potential fluorophore with tremendous photoluminescence (PL) properties. The solid-state fluorescence emission spectrum of the H2 L ligand () shows an emission maximum at 456 nm upon excitation at 344 nm, which can be assigned to the intraligand π–π* transition of the aromatic rings. On the other hand, 1′ () displays an emission maximum at 470 nm in the solid state upon excitation at 356 nm. The similarity between the emission bands of H2 L ligand and 1′ indicates that the photoluminescence behavior of 1′ is mainly due to ligand-centered electronic excitation. However, a red shift (14 nm) of the emission band of the compound compared to the parent ligand is observed, which can be attributed to the perturbation caused by the complexation of the ligand with Cd2+ ions.
